elements.content: In this study, we report the formation of a new crystal structure, ZIF-CO3-1, which results from the reaction of Zn2+, 2-methylimidazole, and carbonate. ZIF-CO3-1 can be synthesized solvothermally in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water (H2O) or by utilizing of CO2 gas at various temperatures in DMF/H2O or H2O. This reaction selectively consumes CO2 because CO2 is incorporated in the ZIF as carbonate. CO2 can be quantitatively released by acidifying the ZIF. Powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, FTIR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis were used to characterize the ZIF structure. ZIF-CO3-1 (chemical formula C9H10N4O3Zn2), crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with noncentrosymmetric space group Pba2.

elements.content: When a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water mixture is used in a solvothermal ZIF-8 synthesis, a new ZIF, ZIF-CO3-1, constructed from tetrahedral Zn2+ ions bridged by 2-methylimidazole and carbonate is formed. This resulted from hydrolysis of DMF at high temperature and the incorporation of thus-formed carbonate in the new framework. ZIF-CO3-1 can also be synthesized by utilizing CO2 gas in conditions under which DMF does not hydrolyze, thus being a suitable material for CO2 capture and storage.
elements.clean_text: When a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water mixture is used in a solvothermal ZIF-8 synthesis, a new ZIF, ZIF-CO3-1, constructed from tetrahedral Zn2+ ions bridged by 2-methylimidazole and carbonate is formed. This resulted from hydrolysis of DMF at high temperature and the incorporation of thus-formed carbonate in the new framework. ZIF-CO3-1 can also be synthesized by utilizing CO2 gas in conditions under which DMF does not hydrolyze, thus being a suitable material for CO2 capture and storage.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic–organic hybrid materials with remarkable properties that are constructed from metal cations or clusters and bridging organic ligands. The high surface areas and wide range of pore architectures associated with MOFs make them attractive for applications in gas separations and storage, catalysis, and chemical sensing. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a subclass of MOFs and crystallize with zeolite topologies. In ZIF structures, the tetrahedral aluminosilicate units of zeolites are replaced by tetrahedral transition-metal ions (most commonly Zn or Co) bridged by imidazolate ligands. ZIFs are porous crystalline materials with large surface areas (>1000 m2·g–1) as well as exceptional chemical and thermal stability (∼400 °C). Because of these excellent properties, ZIFs have been studied for gas storage applications and gas separation membranes. Therefore, there is interest in the synthesis of new ZIF structures. Many attempts have been made to control the pore size and functionality of ZIFs by altering the synthesis conditions, the metal cation, and the organic linker. Also templates/structure-directing agents and the solvent can affect the synthesis of ZIFs. The mixed-linker approach is one of the strategies used to design new ZIF frameworks and architectures. Wu et al. has reported the formation of five zeolitic imidazolate structures with four different 4-conneted topologies by using a mixed-ligand strategy. This study demonstrates the dramatic effect of subtle changes in the experimental conditions such as the solvent or ligand ratio on the synthesis. In this study, we report the synthesis of a new ZIF in the presence of a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water (H2O) mixture in ZIF-8 synthesis. ZIF-8, Zn(2-methylimidazole)2, is a prototypical ZIF having sodalite (SOD) topology. It has a cage size of 11.6 Å with a pore aperture of 3.4 Å and has been shown to adsorb small molecules. ZIF-8 was originally synthesized in DMF under solvothermal conditions, and recently it was reported that it can also be synthesized at room temperature in methanol or H2O. Interestingly, we found that using DMF and H2O as cosolvents results in hydrolysis of DMF at temperatures above 110 °C and the formation of a second ligand (carbonate) in the framework in addition to 2-methylimidazole. The fact that carbonate comes from hydrolysis of DMF but not from atmospheric CO2 at high temperatures was verified because the same product can still be obtained by performing the synthesis in DMF/H2O under N2 at high temperatures. This new framework, ZIF-CO3-1, has a significantly different crystal structure and properties compared to ZIF-8. The formation of new MOFs due to hydrolysis of DMF has been reported. However, in those cases, the resultant dimethylamine or the formate ion from hydrolysis of DMF was incorporated in the framework, but no involvement of carbonate was reported. The formation of carbonate during a ZIF-8 synthesis in DMF/H2O suggested that it may be possible to adsorb CO2 and form ZIF-CO3-1 without hydrolysis of DMF.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are inorganic-organic hybrid materials with remarkable properties that are constructed from metal cations or clusters and bridging organic ligands. The high surface areas and wide range of pore architectures associated with MOFs make them attractive for applications in gas separations and storage, catalysis, and chemical sensing. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a subclass of MOFs and crystallize with zeolite topologies. In ZIF structures, the tetrahedral aluminosilicate units of zeolites are replaced by tetrahedral transition-metal ions (most commonly Zn or Co) bridged by imidazolate ligands. ZIFs are porous crystalline materials with large surface areas (>1000 m2⋅g-1) as well as exceptional chemical and thermal stability (~400 °C). Because of these excellent properties, ZIFs have been studied for gas storage applications and gas separation membranes. Therefore, there is interest in the synthesis of new ZIF structures. Many attempts have been made to control the pore size and functionality of ZIFs by altering the synthesis conditions, the metal cation, and the organic linker. Also templates/structure-directing agents and the solvent can affect the synthesis of ZIFs. The mixed-linker approach is one of the strategies used to design new ZIF frameworks and architectures. Wu et al. has reported the formation of five zeolitic imidazolate structures with four different 4-conneted topologies by using a mixed-ligand strategy. This study demonstrates the dramatic effect of subtle changes in the experimental conditions such as the solvent or ligand ratio on the synthesis. In this study, we report the synthesis of a new ZIF in the presence of a N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF)/water (H2O) mixture in ZIF-8 synthesis. ZIF-8, Zn(2-methylimidazole)2, is a prototypical ZIF having sodalite (SOD) topology. It has a cage size of 11.6 Å with a pore aperture of 3.4 Å and has been shown to adsorb small molecules. ZIF-8 was originally synthesized in DMF under solvothermal conditions, and recently it was reported that it can also be synthesized at room temperature in methanol or H2O. Interestingly, we found that using DMF and H2O as cosolvents results in hydrolysis of DMF at temperatures above 110 °C and the formation of a second ligand (carbonate) in the framework in addition to 2-methylimidazole. The fact that carbonate comes from hydrolysis of DMF but not from atmospheric CO2 at high temperatures was verified because the same product can still be obtained by performing the synthesis in DMF/H2O under N2 at high temperatures. This new framework, ZIF-CO3-1, has a significantly different crystal structure and properties compared to ZIF-8. The formation of new MOFs due to hydrolysis of DMF has been reported. However, in those cases, the resultant dimethylamine or the formate ion from hydrolysis of DMF was incorporated in the framework, but no involvement of carbonate was reported. The formation of carbonate during a ZIF-8 synthesis in DMF/H2O suggested that it may be possible to adsorb CO2 and form ZIF-CO3-1 without hydrolysis of DMF.

elements.content: The rapid growth in industrialization and energy consumption has resulted in a steep increase in CO2 emission to the atmosphere mostly from combustion of fossil fuels, oils, and natural gas. Thus, the development of efficient methods for the capture and storage of CO2 has drawn attention in recent years. Amine scrubbing, which involves the chemisorption of CO2 in an aqueous solution containing an alkanolamine, is a commercial process that is quite efficient. However, this method has several disadvantages such as a high energy requirement for the regeneration of alkanolamine and the necessity to use inhibitors for corrosion control. Zeolites, which are aluminosilicate materials with high porosity and stability, are also studied for the capture of CO2 and have shown faster adsorption and lower energy requirement compared to alkanolamines. However, zeolites tend to get saturated with H2O vapor present in the flue gas, thus having reduced adsorption capacity over time. Another material of high interest as a CO2 adsorbent is activated carbon. This has the advantage of not being affected by the presence of H2O but has lower capacity at low pressure because of the uniform electric potential on the surface. Both MOFs and ZIFs have the ability to capture large amounts of CO2. However, the higher chemical and thermal stability of ZIFs compared to MOFs make them more suitable candidates for industrial applications. Banerjee and co-workers have reported the synthesis of several ZIFs based on a variety of imidazole linkers that have shown selective adsorption of CO2 from CO2/CO mixtures and a large CO2 storage capacity (82.6 L of CO2 per 1 L of ZIF at 273 K for ZIF-69). In our study, the carbonate in the ZIF-CO3-1 structure can be derived from CO2 during the synthesis. The synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1 utilizing CO2 was studied in DMF/H2O and pure H2O at various temperatures. The reaction conditions were chosen in such a way that DMF does not undergo significant hydrolysis, providing CO3 2– for reaction in the DMF/H2O system. In fact, it was found that ZIF-CO3-1 can form in a reaction mixture containing Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 2-methylimidazole in the presence of CO2 gas even at room temperature in a DMF/H2O system as well as in pure H2O. In the absence of CO2, only ZIF-8 forms. The CO2 capture in this process is highly selective for CO2 because it is part of the framework versus just being adsorbed into the pores. N2 adsorption analysis has shown that ZIF-CO3-1 has minimal porosity and thus is relatively dense compared to other ZIFs, which as a fact is an advantage in this instance because it cannot uptake any other gas molecule in the structure. The bound CO2 can be released from ZIF-CO3-1 by acidification, and the ZIF can be easily regenerated in H2O by neutralizing the acid followed by exposure to CO2. The synthesis, structure, and CO2 uptake are described below.

elements.content: 2-Methylimidazole was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and methanol were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All of the starting materials were used without further purification. Experimental procedures were performed in air, N2 (99.998% purity), and CO2 (99.99% purity).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

2-Methylimidazole was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Zinc nitrate hexahydrate, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and methanol were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All of the starting materials were used without further purification. Experimental procedures were performed in air, N2 (99.998% purity), and CO2 (99.99% purity).

elements.content: The synthesis was carried out by using a modification of the ZIF-8 solvothermal synthesis. A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 24 h at 140 °C. The resultant white ZIF-CO3-1 crystals were washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL × 3) and dried in air overnight. Yield: 36.46%. Elem anal. Calcd for C9H10N4O3Zn2Zn2(MIM)2(CO3): C, 30.62; H, 2.86; N, 15.87; O, 13.60; Zn, 37.05. Found: C, 29.44; H, 2.83; N, 15.00; O, 19.66; Zn, 33.07.
elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1

The synthesis was carried out by using a modification of the ZIF-8 solvothermal synthesis. A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 24 h at 140 °C. The resultant white ZIF-CO3-1 crystals were washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL × 3) and dried in air overnight. Yield: 36.46%. Elem anal. Calcd for C9H10N4O3Zn2Zn2(MIM)2(CO3): C, 30.62; H, 2.86; N, 15.87; O, 13.60; Zn, 37.05. Found: C, 29.44; H, 2.83; N, 15.00; O, 19.66; Zn, 33.07.

elements.content: A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The flask was sealed, and CO2 gas was purged through the flask for 15 min at room temperature. Then the solution was kept under a blanket of CO2 and heated to 85 °C in a sand bath for 24 h. The white precipitate formed was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF (10 mL × 3). The process was repeated at room temperature in DMF/H2O and deionized (DI) H2O. All reactions resulted in white ZIF-CO3-1 precipitates that were collected and washed in a similar manner. The control reactions were carried out by using N2 gas in place of CO2 in each solvent system and temperature. No precipitation was observed for the control reactions.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Capture during the Synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1

A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 250 mL round-bottomed flask. The flask was sealed, and CO2 gas was purged through the flask for 15 min at room temperature. Then the solution was kept under a blanket of CO2 and heated to 85 °C in a sand bath for 24 h. The white precipitate formed was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF (10 mL × 3). The process was repeated at room temperature in DMF/H2O and deionized (DI) H2O. All reactions resulted in white ZIF-CO3-1 precipitates that were collected and washed in a similar manner. The control reactions were carried out by using N2 gas in place of CO2 in each solvent system and temperature. No precipitation was observed for the control reactions.

elements.content: A total of 0.0302 mg of ZIF-CO3-1 was transferred to a 20 mL vial with a rubber stopper. A total of 1.00 mL of 2 N HCl was added, and the vial was immediately sealed and the solid completely dissolved to give a colorless solution. It was connected to a manometer (Figure S1 in the , SI), and the released CO2 was measured in triplicate. Average amount of CO2 released: experimental, 2.71 × 10–3 mol·g–1; calcd for C9H10N2O3Zn2, 2.84 × 10–3 mol·g–1.
elements.clean_text:
Release and Quantification of CO2 from ZIF-CO3-1

A total of 0.0302 mg of ZIF-CO3-1 was transferred to a 20 mL vial with a rubber stopper. A total of 1.00 mL of 2 N HCl was added, and the vial was immediately sealed and the solid completely dissolved to give a colorless solution. It was connected to a manometer (Figure S1 in the , SI), and the released CO2 was measured in triplicate. Average amount of CO2 released: experimental, 2.71 × 10-3 mol⋅g-1; calcd for C9H10N2O3Zn2, 2.84 × 10-3 mol⋅g-1.

elements.content: A total of 0.0114 mg of ZIF-CO3-1 was transferred to a 250 mL round-bottomed flask, followed by the addition of 0.50 mL of 2 N HCl. Then 17.6 mL of DI H2O and 0.5 mL of 2 N NaOH were added. The flask was sealed and purged with CO2 for 15 min at room temperature. Then the solution was kept under a blanket of CO2 and room temperature for 24 h. A white ZIF-CO3-1 precipitate formed and was centrifuged and washed with DI H2O (10 mL × 3).
elements.clean_text:
Recovery of the CO2 Capture Process after Release

A total of 0.0114 mg of ZIF-CO3-1 was transferred to a 250 mL round-bottomed flask, followed by the addition of 0.50 mL of 2 N HCl. Then 17.6 mL of DI H2O and 0.5 mL of 2 N NaOH were added. The flask was sealed and purged with CO2 for 15 min at room temperature. Then the solution was kept under a blanket of CO2 and room temperature for 24 h. A white ZIF-CO3-1 precipitate formed and was centrifuged and washed with DI H2O (10 mL × 3).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was obtained with a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) attenuated total reflectance spectra were obtained by using a Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy images were obtained using a Zeiss SUPRA 40 scanning electron microscope. N2 adsorption was performed using a Quantachrome AS1 autosorb. H2 adsorption was performed using a high-pressure volumetric analyzer (Micromeritics, HPVA-100). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained using a Pyris 1 thermogravimetric analyzer. Elemental analysis was performed by Galbraith Laboratories Inc., Knoxville, TN. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data on ZIF-CO3-1 was collected from a prismatic crystal on a Rigaku Saturn 724+ diffractometer at room temperature using synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å) at Beamline I19, Diamond Light Source, Oxfordshire, U.K. Data reduction and numerical absorption correction were applied using CryAlisPro. The structure was solved by direct methods. Non-H atoms were located directly from difference Fourier maps. Framework H atoms were placed geometrically and constrained using the riding model to the parent atoms. Final structure refinement was done using the SHELX program by minimizing the sum of squared deviations of F 2 using a full-matrix technique. A summary of the crystal data and structure refinement of ZIF-CO3-1 is given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was obtained with a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) attenuated total reflectance spectra were obtained by using a Nicolet 380 FTIR spectrometer. Scanning electron microscopy images were obtained using a Zeiss SUPRA 40 scanning electron microscope. N2 adsorption was performed using a Quantachrome AS1 autosorb. H2 adsorption was performed using a high-pressure volumetric analyzer (Micromeritics, HPVA-100). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained using a Pyris 1 thermogravimetric analyzer. Elemental analysis was performed by Galbraith Laboratories Inc., Knoxville, TN. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data on ZIF-CO3-1 was collected from a prismatic crystal on a Rigaku Saturn 724+ diffractometer at room temperature using synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.6889 Å) at Beamline I19, Diamond Light Source, Oxfordshire, U.K. Data reduction and numerical absorption correction were applied using CryAlisPro. The structure was solved by direct methods. Non-H atoms were located directly from difference Fourier maps. Framework H atoms were placed geometrically and constrained using the riding model to the parent atoms. Final structure refinement was done using the SHELX program by minimizing the sum of squared deviations of F 2 using a full-matrix technique. A summary of the crystal data and structure refinement of ZIF-CO3-1 is given in Table .

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data revealed that the new ZIF reported herein (denoted as ZIF-CO3-1 hereafter) crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pba2, whereas ZIF-8 crystallizes in a cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of ZIF-CO3-1 contains one Zn, one 2-methylimidazole ligand, and a half triangular carbonate ligand. The presence of carbonate ligands was confirmed by IR and synthesis experiments, which will be discussed later. Each Zn atom is connected to two 2-methylimidazole ligands (via N) and two triangular carbonate ligands (via O) to form a ZnN2O2 tetrahedron (Figure a). Each carbonate ion links to four Zn atoms, while each 2-methylimidazolate ligand binds to two Zn atoms. Different from the ZIF-8 structure, where the Zn tetrahedra are isolated and connected by 2-methylimidazole ligands, Zn tetrahedra in ZIF-CO3-1 form dimers by sharing O2 from the carbonates. The Zn dimer is further connected to four adjacent Zn dimers through 2-methylimidazolate ligands, forming a 2D layer within the ab plane (Figure b). The layers are stacked along the c axis and connected through the triangular carbonate ligands to form a 3D framework, as shown in Figure c.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data revealed that the new ZIF reported herein (denoted as ZIF-CO3-1 hereafter) crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pba2, whereas ZIF-8 crystallizes in a cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of ZIF-CO3-1 contains one Zn, one 2-methylimidazole ligand, and a half triangular carbonate ligand. The presence of carbonate ligands was confirmed by IR and synthesis experiments, which will be discussed later. Each Zn atom is connected to two 2-methylimidazole ligands (via N) and two triangular carbonate ligands (via O) to form a ZnN2O2 tetrahedron (Figure a). Each carbonate ion links to four Zn atoms, while each 2-methylimidazolate ligand binds to two Zn atoms. Different from the ZIF-8 structure, where the Zn tetrahedra are isolated and connected by 2-methylimidazole ligands, Zn tetrahedra in ZIF-CO3-1 form dimers by sharing O2 from the carbonates. The Zn dimer is further connected to four adjacent Zn dimers through 2-methylimidazolate ligands, forming a 2D layer within the ab plane (Figure b). The layers are stacked along the c axis and connected through the triangular carbonate ligands to form a 3D framework, as shown in Figure c.

elements.content: A close observation of its crystal structure reveals that Zn–N and Zn–O bond lengths in this framework are very close to the Zn–N bond length in ZIF-8, which is 1.965 Å. However, the N–Zn–N and O–Zn–O bond angles (120.0° and 98.22°, respectively; Table S1 in the ) in this framework appear to be significantly deviated from the ideal tetrahedral bond angle, in contrast to the N–Zn–N bond angle in ZIF-8, which is 110.9°.

elements.content: From single-crystal X-ray diffraction data, it is difficult to know whether the triangular ligand is nitrate or carbonate. We initially thought that the triangular ligand was nitrate, possibly coming from the zinc source Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. However, it was found that the same structure could be formed with the use of ZnCl2 as the zinc source, and thus the triangular ligand could not be nitrate. Also it is worth noting that the formation of this structure required reaction temperatures higher than 110 °C with Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in the synthesis. However, when the synthesis was performed with carbonate added to the synthesis, the ZIF-CO3-1 phase could be obtained at temperatures as low as 85 °C, which indicated that the triangular linker was carbonate. Also the necessity of high temperature for the generation of carbonate from the original reaction mixture when carbonate was not added externally is consistent. Results from elemental analysis confirmed that this ligand in fact was carbonate, according to the weight percentage of each element. FTIR spectroscopy (Figure ) provided further evidence for bonding in ZIF-CO3-1. Two strong bands at 1583.2 and 1369.2 cm–1 are attributed to the asymmetric stretching modes of carbonate, whereas the medium band at 827.6 cm–1 is assigned for the bending mode of carbonate. The medium band at 430.9 cm–1 arises from the Zn–N (in imidazole) stretching mode typically observed in a ZIF. The presence of carbonate in addition to 2-methylimidazole has resulted in an entirely new set of properties for ZIF-CO3-1 compared to ZIF-8, which is constructed from tetrahedral Zn2+ ions bridged by four 2-methylimidazole units.

elements.content: On the basis of the structural and experimental results and optimal synthesis conditions, the following mechanism is suggested for the formation of carbonate in the reaction mixture. The solvent, DMF, hydrolyzes into formic acid and dimethylamine at elevated temperatures (reaction ). ( CH 3 ) 2 N CHO + H 2 O → HCOOH + ( CH 3 ) 2 HN Formic acid can decompose in two different pathways, leading to the following products. HCOOH → CO + H 2 O ⁡ ( decarbonylation ) HCOOH → CO 2 + H 2 ⁡ ( decarboxylation ) Decarboxylation (reaction ) is favored when the pH of the medium is greater than 4. The pH of our reaction mixture was around 7 before and after the synthesis. In aqueous media, H2O catalyzes the decarboxylation, so that the formation of H2 takes one H from HCOOH and the other H from H2O. This implies that the addition of H2O to the medium provides all of the necessary conditions for hydrolysis of DMF and the formation of HCOOH to ultimately produce CO2. CO2 can produce carbonate in the aqueous solution, which is then incorporated in the ZIF-CO3-1 crystal structure.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data reveal that the incorporation of carbonate in this framework resulted in a denser framework compared to ZIF-8. The presence of much smaller CO3 2– as a bridging linker compared to an imidazole linker caused this structure to be closely packed compared to a conventional ZIF. Thus, ZIF-CO3-1 considerably deviates from a typical ZIF; however, we use the term “ZIF” in its name because it was derived from a modified ZIF-8 synthesis. Owing to the dense framework, ZIF-CO3-1 shows low N2 uptake (Figure S2 in the ) and thus low porosity. The current studies on gas adsorption at high pressure do not show any significant adsorption of H2 gas up to 100 bar. Also, it does not adsorb any H2O at 100% relative humidity.

elements.content: The PXRD pattern of ZIF-CO3-1 (Figure ) reveals the high crystallinity of the new structure. However, the higher angle of the first reflection compared to that of ZIF-8 implies that the incorporation of carbonates leads to a smaller unit cell compared to ZIF-8. Its high correspondence with the pattern simulated from single-crystal data proves that the structure of the bulk material is the same as that of the single crystal.

elements.content: TGA data (Figure ) indicate a plateau region with no significant weight loss below 450 °C. This implies that there are no guest solvent molecules (DMF and H2O in this synthesis) trapped inside the framework. After 450 °C, it decomposes into ZnO (as confirmed by PXRD) with a weight loss of 54.76%, which agrees quite well with the calculated weight loss of 53.90% for decomposition of ZIF-CO3-1 to ZnO. ZIF-8 also is thermally stable up to ∼450–500 °C; thus, the presence of the carbonate group in ZIF-CO3-1 has not lead to lower thermal stability. Additionally, CO2 can be stored in the ZIF-CO3-1 structure without loss up to 450 °C, which can be compared with other ZIFs such as ZIF-68, ZIF-69, or ZIF-70, which decompose and lose CO2 at temperatures from 350 to 390 °C.

elements.content: The CO2 capture ability of ZIF-CO3-1 was measured in the DMF/H2O system using conditions under which DMF does not significantly hydrolyze, supplying carbonate for the reaction. It was observed that under normal solvothermal conditions ZIF-CO3-1 does not precipitate at reaction temperatures below 110 °C. Therefore, 85 °C was chosen as the upper temperature limit for the CO2 capture experiment. The reaction mixture started to become cloudy while CO2 was passed over the solution, and over time upon heating, more precipitation was observed. The product was characterized using PXRD, and it was verified that it indeed was ZIF-CO3-1. A control reaction was carried out at the same time by purging N2 to the sealed reaction vessel in order to eliminate CO2. Upon heating at 85 °C for 24 h, no precipitation was observed for this reaction. This further verified the requirement of CO2 for the reaction to be completed. The sequestration of CO2 by ZIF-CO3-1 was further studied at room temperature in the DMF/H2O system as well as pure DI H2O. Surprisingly, CO2 was absorbed in both solvent systems at room temperature, instantly forming ZIF-CO3-1 in pure H2O. These results show the flexibility of the ZIF-CO3-1 system, which can be employed over a wide range of temperatures. The reactive binding of CO2 in the form of carbonate circumvents many of the problems associated with conventional adsorption of CO2 using MOFs. Typically, the flue gas from a power plant consists of 15% CO2, 75% N2, 5% H2O, 3% O2, and trace amounts of sulfur oxides and nitrogen oxides. Thus, an ideal adsorbent for CO2 should exhibit high selectivity for CO2 in gas mixtures. In MOFs, the selectivity for CO2 is often accomplished by postfunctionalizing the pore surfaces with amine groups to mimic the chemisorption in conventional amine scrubbers. However, these methods add extra cost for generation of the adsorbent in addition to the high energy required for the synthesis of a MOF, which involves solvothermal methods and long reaction periods. In ZIF-CO3-1, excellent selectivity is acquired as CO2 participates in the synthesis, thus saving energy and costs. The relatively high density prevents other gas molecules from being adsorbed. Another problem with many MOF adsorbents is the low stability in air and moisture; for example, MOF-5, once its pores are evacuated, rapidly degrades in air from the hydrolysis of metal–oxygen bonds. The flue gas from postcombustion in a plant has a considerable amount of H2O; thus, the stability of a MOF in H2O is essential for industrial applications. ZIF-CO3-1 is quite stable in air and can be made in H2O, thus being suitable for that type of application.

elements.content: The capture of CO2 from a flue gas stream by the conversion of CaO to CaCO3 is also being considered. However, chemisorption takes place at temperatures from 50 to 300 °C, and higher temperatures are required for the formation of bulk carbonate. Moreover, the sorbent material is regenerated via calcination at temperatures as high as 800–900 °C, consuming a large amount of energy, which may also lead to deterioration of the sorbent material. The method of CO2 capture reported herein, which involves a solution mixture transforming into a solid after reaction with CO2, parallels other CO2 capture techniques that involve a gas–liquid reaction that results in a solid product. For example, the absorption of CO2 into a caustic solution such as NaOH or Ca(OH)2 to form a solid carbonate involves the conversion of Na2CO3 into CaCO3 by subsequent reaction with Ca(OH)2. CaCO3 is then thermally decomposed to release gaseous CO2. One of the limitations of this technique is the energy requirement for the extraction of Ca(OH)2 from its natural source limestone. Capture of CO2 in the form of a solid can be achieved by using amines. For example, Zheng et al. reported that the use of a triethylenetetramine/ethanol mixture results in a precipitate after absorption of CO2. This was proposed to be energy efficient because the precipitate can be easily separated and regenerated by heat as opposed to liquid amine scrubbing systems, which require a large amount of energy for solvent regeneration. A major difference between these systems and ZIF-CO3-1 is that the ZIF-CO3-1 system requires a chemical reaction (pH change) for regeneration as opposed to thermal decomposition.

Capture of CO2 in the form of a solid can be achieved by using amines. For example, Zheng et al. reported that the use of a triethylenetetramine/ethanol mixture results in a precipitate after absorption of CO2. elements.content: The postcombustion gas stream is normally at a pressure of ∼1 bar and a temperature of ∼40 °C. The ZIF-CO3-1 synthesis reported in this work captures CO2 at temperatures ranging from room temperature to 85 °C and close to atmospheric pressure (1.01325 bar), and hence it would be an ideal alternative for MOFs that show high CO2 uptake at only high pressures. The theoretical CO2 capacity of ZIF-CO3-1 under these conditions is 12.5% by weight, and experimental studies of CO2 release give a comparable value (11.9 wt %). This is quite comparable to the CO2 uptake capacity of the most common commercial amine, a 30% monoethanolamine solution, which is 13.4% under the usual conditions. Liu et al. has reported the CO2 uptake capacities of several MOFs ranging from 7.8 to 35.2 wt %, with most of them lying between 12 and 14 wt % at 1 bar and 298 K. Although some of these MOFs have much higher CO2 capacities, most are synthesized in toxic organic solvents and at high temperatures. Thus, ZIF-CO3-1 provides several advantages including the ability to be used even in pure H2O, at temperatures as low as room tempearture, without the requirement of presynthesis and a reasonably good CO2 uptake capacity. The energy requirement for the regeneration of a MOF adsorbent is another challenge that arises with the stronger binding of CO2. In our system, CO2 can be released from ZIF-CO3-1 via acidification at room temperature, and upon neutralization and exposure to CO2, the entire process of ZIF-CO3-1 generation by sequestration of CO2 can be repeated. The PXRD pattern (Figure S3 in the ) of the product obtained after three cycles of release and regeneration confirms that the crystal structure of ZIF-CO3-1 is preserved after this process. Therefore, it does not require high temperature or low pressure for the regeneration process.

elements.content: A new structure, ZIF-CO3-1, based on the ZIF-8 synthesis has been prepared from Zn2+ ions bridged by two mixed ligands, 2-methylimdazole and carbonate. The presence of H2O in the synthesis leads to hydrolysis of DMF at high temperatures, which gives rise to the formation of carbonate, which is incorporated as a second ligand in the ZIF structure. The newly formed framework is relatively dense but is highly crystalline, with high thermal stability similar to ZIF-8. The synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1 can also be achieved by exposure to gaseous CO2 in DMF/H2O or H2O under conditions similar to those of the postcombustion gas stream from an industrial plant, thus providing an excellent material for selective CO2 capture. CO2 can be quantitatively released (∼12% by weight), and the CO2 capture process can be repeated without significant energy requirement.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new structure, ZIF-CO3-1, based on the ZIF-8 synthesis has been prepared from Zn2+ ions bridged by two mixed ligands, 2-methylimdazole and carbonate. The presence of H2O in the synthesis leads to hydrolysis of DMF at high temperatures, which gives rise to the formation of carbonate, which is incorporated as a second ligand in the ZIF structure. The newly formed framework is relatively dense but is highly crystalline, with high thermal stability similar to ZIF-8. The synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1 can also be achieved by exposure to gaseous CO2 in DMF/H2O or H2O under conditions similar to those of the postcombustion gas stream from an industrial plant, thus providing an excellent material for selective CO2 capture. CO2 can be quantitatively released (~12% by weight), and the CO2 capture process can be repeated without significant energy requirement.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: The synthesis was carried out by using a modification of the ZIF-8 solvothermal synthesis. A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 24 h at 140 °C. The resultant white ZIF-CO3-1 crystals were washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL × 3) and dried in air overnight. Yield: 36.46%. Elem anal. cln_elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of ZIF-CO3-1

The synthesis was carried out by using a modification of the ZIF-8 solvothermal synthesis. A solid mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.264 g, 0.87 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.074 g, 0.87 mmol) was dissolved in 17.6 mL of a DMF/H2O mixture (10:1, v/v) in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 24 h at 140 °C. The resultant white ZIF-CO3-1 crystals were washed with DMF (10 mL) and methanol (10 mL × 3) and dried in air overnight. Yield: 36.46%. Elem anal. cln_elements.content: TGA data (Figure ) indicate a plateau region with no significant weight loss below 450 °C. This implies that there are no guest solvent molecules (DMF and H2O in this synthesis) trapped inside the framework. After 450 °C, it decomposes into ZnO (as confirmed by PXRD) with a weight loss of 54.76%, which agrees quite well with the calculated weight loss of 53.90% for decomposition of ZIF-CO3-1 to ZnO. ZIF-8 also is thermally stable up to ∼450–500 °C; thus, the presence of the carbonate group in ZIF-CO3-1 has not lead to lower thermal stability. Additionally, CO2 can be stored in the ZIF-CO3-1 structure without loss up to 450 °C, which can be compared with other ZIFs such as ZIF-68, ZIF-69, or ZIF-70, which decompose and lose CO2 at temperatures from 350 to 390 °C.
